choices.text:
preserving the few videos of my entire childhood that exist. They are stored on DVDs, on my external hard drive, and on server backup discs sent to a friend in the US. Each is liable to damage, destruction, or irredeemable watermarking; each might fail during my young adult years, the adolescence of my sixteen-year-old self. All I want—what I’ve always wanted—is to see the tracer bullets chase the planes when the sky runs fiery-red, to feel the explosion in my belly and on my face, to see the smoke catching the sunlight in my eyes on dark nights and feel my ears ring and my nose fill with ash. Do you know what I mean? (Shavonne, 16 years old)

This fragmentation and distrust extends to displacement. Those who have been forced to leave their homes report experiencing independent acts of repair as ways to keep trauma as a constant in the backdrop of life. The upkeep of artifacts to aid in remembering the past can be a goal of their own, standing independent from the outcome of ethnic or religious conflict.

The ongoing repair of artifacts from the present or past, never ending preservation of all possible voices and their passive protest against erasure, allows traumatized communities to gain agency and thus offers hope. Reparation may, occasionally, be the ability to be resilient. This resilient ability challenges the assumption of reparation as necessary only to address the seeming inequities arising from traumatic acts that disproportionately discriminate against and burden one party (Pan
